If you're in the area and just want some regular ol American breakfast (they even have Latino breakfast items) this place ain't too bad.
author: Mila B.

description: Was delighted to meet a friend for what would be considered a mini community meeting and I thoroughly enjoyed the food on the table in our server! The place was full on a Monday afternoon and getting a table was a little difficult but I did get one 2 to 3 minutes after arriving. The young lady that served me while we waited for my guests was very patient and very courteous so customer service was ever so present! They have a wide selection of food on the menu including breakfast items which I would have thought would not have been served after 11 a.m. But yet they were available to the customers. So even though my colleague was late they did not mind so much that I was holding up a table for 4 and they did serve us promptly once she got there. Apparently there are also items Latino menu type items that were  not on the menu so you should ask or possibly there may be a secondary menu. All in all a great selection for food the food was presented in an appetizing way and I cannot even begin to say thank you to the server she just was ever so on top of things! I will use it whenever I have personal or business to conduct in the Mission District it's a great location thank you.
author: Jim S.

description:
Many folks may walk right by the Red Cafe without even realizing they did so -- indeed, it's easy to miss among the color and clamor of the 24th/Mission area.  But now that you've read this, you aren't allowed to do that any more.

A mix between an American and Latino diner, it's the most unique combo I've seen of the two in my time here in SF.  (What it's NOT is "Tex-Mex" or anything resembling that)  Think traditional American egg breakfasts with a side of tortilla, plantains, and beans (casamiento platanos) or breakfast burrito with a side of hash browns.  Not to mention the SF staple of freshly-squeezed orange juice -- something that transcends even the highest border wall.

What I love about Red Cafe the most (aside from the above-mentioned side of plantains) is its authentic feel...Latino families enjoying brunch after Mass and it being a Latino-run business in general.  I hope we gringos can find a way to enjoy it without taking over and pushing out the OGs.  

I recently found out the name is derived from the owner's home country:  The coffee beans are ripe for picking when they turn red.

PROS:
-close to 24th/Mission BART
-never a too-long wait (max 20 minutes)
-authentic and good-quality food
-plaintains for breakfast

CONS:
-street musicians can sometimes take over the place
author: Em C.

description:
This place is the bee's knees & the spider's ankles.  The service from the boys is spot-on; the girls could be a WHOLE LOT friendlier.  The girl behind the counter (the one who wears the crocheted hairband ALL the time) can be a bit of a douche, but just ignore her attitude and concentrate on the food.

The breakfast here is solid - tasty and dependable.  You must try the fried plantain breakfast - it rocks!  The country scramble with ham & avocado is another one of my faves.
author: Ciara M.

description:
Does the vent work above the grill?  Not sure if i was there on a bad day but a fog of fried smoke filled the top half of the cafe.  

After enjoying the great food I walked to Walgreens, bought a bottle of frebeze so that the rest of my office would not have to smell my breakfast all day long.
author: Aus B.

description: Forget those other breakfast places with the long lines on a Sunday morning. This place is cheap, the food is good, and the staff friendly. I would've walked by this place if I hadn't found it on Yelp. And oh, their refried beans are NOT made with lard as is often the case with a cheap Mission eatery.
author: Dan E.

description:
Ladies cook the food,
Chilaquiles and coffee
make my tummy smile.
author: Sam W.

description:
Solid breakfast food.  Rarely a line outdside. 1 block from my place.  Cool.

I recommend the platanos and eggs, huevos rancheros or chilaquiles.
author: sam p.

description:
A small but solid step up from standard diner food. 

What's great about Red Cafe is the service. 
All the waitstaff is well above average,  and this one guy in particular is super. His English is a little shaky but he makes up for it being extra careful when taking orders. You can see him concentrating and carefully LISTENING -something that's pretty rare in service workers.
So when my friend puts in an annoyingly picky order,  he gets right every time.  Plus he is super polite and quick.  

and oh, the place is also unusually clean.
author: Puffy P.

description:
Terrific American breakfast/lunch diner food with lots of Mexican alternatives. Plus, the greaze here is very reasonably priced. 

My favorite is the Omlette Nopal, an omlette with cheese and nopalitos (tender, pickled cactus). That with a side of bacon and a cup of their medocre coffee and I'm set. It is kind of weird that they put the cheese atop your omlette though.

This place has ALWAYS been a diner, though sadly it used to be the kind with a jukebox at every table. But no longer. Oh well, where else am I ginna get my cactus omlette?
author: Jeremy W.

description:
I've walked by this place 800 million times without stopping in. Last weekend I was torn between the french toast ($4!!) and the plantains (plantains!!). I went with the latter and felt the shameful joy most closely resembling the kind one might feel while having ice cream for breakfast or a bacon-wrapped hot dog while Jewish. You guys, we're talking like two whole fried plantains, served with beans and sour cream.

As an added bonus, we got live mariachi tunes to accompany our brunch. The place is kinda cheapo, though. But I've been looking for a simple diner that isn't out in the farthest reaches of the Sunset (quite literally - Bashful Bull II is on like 47th and Taraval).
author: Amy Z.

description: If you eat here, be sure and try the oatmeal pancakes, they are fabulous!
author: Courtney L.

description:
I've been twice for brunch. Service seems friendlier later in the 'morning' (i.e., in the early afternoon) once the crowd thins a bit.

I've had the chiliquiles the first time and a plantain dish the second time. Both times someone else ordered hash browns so I got to share them. The chiliquiles are great. The beans they serve on the side are super tasty. The plantain dish came with awesome plantains, good queso, fried eggs (yolk was runny which is good in my opinion and the waitress had encouraged me to get rancheros sauce on the eggs which was great), a tasty ball of rice and beans (not sure what this is called), and flour tortillas on the side. Filling, cheap, and a great diner experience. I may get toast next time because I could not figure out how to wipe up the yolk & rancheros sauce with the tortillas...

Note that the fresh-squeezed OJ is a way better beverage choice than coffee here. Also, note that the bench seats are uncomfortable and the place can be crowded with no-nonsense service earlier in the day.
author: J Y L.

description:
A great find for breakfast in the Mission.  These folks take great pride in serving fresh, simple food, and you can sense that from the second you walk into this clean, airy, minimally decorated coffee shop.

They prepare the food right behind the counter, so I sat and watched as they whipped together my huevos rancheros along with the meals of other patrons.  I was amazed by the slow, loving care the prep cook took with each dish - right down to a little sprig of parsley on each plate.  

The food was tasty, the coffee was decent, and the service was smiley and efficient.  This was my first time to Red's, but I'm going to go out on a limb and say that as far as coffee-shops/diners go (and they go pretty far in my book), this is the pinnacle.
author: Mike G.

description:
5 stars for the friendly and accommodating staff!

4 stars for the atmosphere. It was crowded without being stuffy, busy without being obnoxiously noisy. My boyfriend and I didn't have to wait long for a seat. The decor is minimal. 

3 stars for the food. Coffee was amazing and the servers consistently went around asking folks if they wanted refill. I was excited to see corned beef hash sandwich on their menu, only to find out that they use the canned ones you can buy from Safeway. Albeit feeling cheated, the sandwich still tasted okay. 

In short, great service, mediocre food, relatively cheap prices. It definitely beats forever waiting in line at Stack's or Chow.
author: Joseph P.

description:
I went  here yesterday on my way to Sacramento.  I wanted something hearty, not terribly expensive or with a scene (Love Bugaloo but  a little "hip"  for my mood. )  and really  near BART..  I Yelped  options, remember seeing the cafe on my Mission excursions, and decided  to give it a try.  (I wanted to waste no time looking for a place.)    This was on a weekday at like 7:45, so  it  wasn't  at all crowded.  The first  thing I did was grunt for coffee.:)  After that neccessity  was taken care  of  I looked at the menu for a quick minute.  Through My Yelping  I  had  an idea of a few items I would particularly  enjoy.    After  looking at the menu I  decided on the corned beef hash.  It  had  some vegeteables  so maybe it was slightly healthy (LOL, right.)  Also worried that my other  main idea , a breakfast buurrito may get over my nice  going to the capitol clothes if I tried to pick it up!  It took like  5 minutes for the hash  to come out.  It  was piping hot  when it came out, and so, so tasty.  The vegetables were a great addition! It  was  just  what I  needed  .. The has browns  it came were delicious  too.   I sopped up a bit of the hash with the  flour tortillas it came  with also.  VERY  nice.   The coffee wasn't the best, but not the worst and did its job.

The place wasn't big and I  could see where it could get crowded on the weekend.     I wouldn't  recommend  it if there is more than one person in a wheelchair in your party or l arge groups in general.    The waitress was attentive and immediately brought me a straw when I asked for one for my coffee. (Again coffee on clothes not great if  I want to  look competent!) The morning radio show on in the background was innocous enough .    Bottom line, I would definitely come back and try other options as well, and  will come for puposas  too sometime!
author: Sascha B.

description:
Atmosphere was very meh, and didn't go with the food. 
Food was good, although our orders weren't quite correct. I had the grilled cheese, which I will almost certainly go back for, but only because it's close to my work. 
Prices are decent. It's basically diner food with slightly cleaner plates.
I would have given four stars except that we had to wait 20 minutes for the (otherwise very nice) waitstaff to notice us so we could get our check and gtfo. 

My lunch break is only so long, gentlemen. 

Seriously, though, good grilled cheese.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Service was fine and the food was just okay.  The chilaquiles weren't anywhere as good as they are at Luna Park (surprising, but so true!).  The decor is soutwestern-dinery, but very, very tiny with cramped seatingn in the booths (hard for even 2 people to fit on one side!).

My omelette and hash browns compared poorly to Pork Store in terms of taste, portion size, seating, atmosphere, and price.
author: Sid D.

description:
The waitress was cheery and efficient. My oatmeal pancakes were delightful. And the price was EXCELLENT.

This is the only place I've been to in San Francisco that I would rate as inexpensive eats. And the food was actually great to boot!
author: Matt W.

description:
We were searching for brunch places to check out and after reading Miriam's review of chilaquiles, it piqued my curiousity to find out what this was so we ventured out to Mission to grab some. 

I had the chilaquiles and platano fritos/plantains on the side and bf had scrambled eggs with ham and cheese. The Chilaquiles was delicious and my first time trying it, scrambled eggs with tortilla chips and the side of beans was tasty and it goes well together. Fried plantains were good, sweet, ripe and great soft texture!
author: Yan M.

description: $6.25 for a plate of delicious French Toast piled so high with strawberries and bananas that you can't even see the toast part when it comes.  The only other thing I've gotten is the breakfast quesadilla, and it was great.   I'm dying to try their other food because it all looks really good, like their fried plantains, omelettes and guacamole but I'm so addicted to their French toast that I haven't been able to try very much other stuff yet.  Well-priced, simple, fresh food with big portions.
author: Susan D.

description:
A whole in the wall place on the corner of 25th & mission.  PLEASE GO AND TRY.

Red Cafe has the best moist, tasty, healthy oatmeal pancakes.  That is all I know, because I get them every time with seasonal fruit on top.  Their hash browns are also very good, crispy and not soggy and greasy and nasty.  Also they allow you to choose to get their omelets without egg yolks.
author: John F.

description:
I ate here today & it was excellent. I had the chilaquiles, very delicious.
My wife got the oatmeal pancakes & they were quite tasty too.
We sat at the counter & everything else being cooked looked amazing, the staff was super nice & they weren't too crowded.
author: chris a.

description:
I don't know how many times I have passed this cafe in the busy mission district. Today my aunt and I just happened to stumble upon it, and I loved it. 

They have food like oatmeal pancakes in addition to the traditional continental breakfast stuff. I will be back. 

They also take ATM, which I love.
author: Ana S.

description:
My wife and I really love coming to this place.

First off, the atmosphere in the place is really awesome.  I don't know how accurate this is, but it seems like everybody who works there is related, so it has that family restaurant vibe.  The workers seem to be walking around smiling and having a good time (with the possible exception of a bad day of course).  

As for the food, we've been in for breakfast several times, and it's turned into our favorite morning place in the city.  The chorizo breakfast burrito is badass (good chorizo, not that crappy greasy stuff that makes me sick) and the french toast is really good too.  Add to that some tasty coffee and this is a really pleasant breakfast.
author: doug s.

description: Horrible service. Good food. I received my tortillas on a dirty plate (must have been used for toast before me).
author: Krishna S.

description: We were looking for a brunch place with no line, and saw that this had 4 stars on yelp and came on down. It was mostly empty, so we were seated right away, two of us on a sunday. we each got the oatmeal pancakes with fruit, the fresh squeezed oj, and shared a side of plantains. The pancakes were good, but nothing spectacular. they tasted like something i could have made at home myself. Not that they were bad, but not sure why all the super raves on yelp. They only carry the imitation maple syrup, but our waitress was helpful and tried to suggest honey as a substitute. The oj was fresh and very tasty, nice and sweet.  The plantains were not bad, but definitely we've had better. They tasted a little greasy, and you have to pay extra for sour cream. A meal for two came out to about $40, so this is definitely a $$ sign place rather than a $ as is listed on the yelp listing. Definitely not expensive ,but not as cheap as the no frills diner setting would suppose you to. Service was good, it was clean. We both got headaches after, but probably just because we're more health nuts used to eating healthier food than this. Anyway, it was A-OK three stars, good, not great. Not a place to trek over to the mission from noe valley from like we did, but maybe good to eat at if you happen to live in the area.
author: Merredith L.

description: 4 stars really? Peoples expectations/standards must be really low in this area! I don't think it was bad at all but 4 stars is definately high.
author: Rio J.

description:
Only in the mission can you get a menu as eclectic as the one at Red's (take your pick - american or mexican standards for breakfast or lunch), all while be serenaded by a mariachi band in the back. It was my I Love The Mission Moment #1511. 

Went with an american breakfast - egg white scramble. Bummed they forgot  1) my toast and 2) to take out the mushrooms, but I'm looking past that thanks to the no charge bananas and strawberries on the side (rather than hash browns), the outstanding shrimp salad I had for dinner later on, and the aforementioned mariachi band.
author: Jason B.

description:
If you're brunching solo and don't want to deal with waiting in a long line by yourself, Red Cafe is the place to go. They'll have you in and out of there with a happy tummy no less. I've sat atop one of the barstools at the counter four times in the last month, and the food has always been delicious. 

Gotta give props for speedy service with a smile.  The servers are friendly, the kitchen is humming,  the atmosphere is low-key, and the bacon is delish.
author: LadyLongLegs L.

description: I had the french slam and it was good. Nice place for breakfast and I live close by. So its got location working for it. =)
author: Genaro R.

description: Excellent breakfast in a classic little diner setting. Hash browns - not homefries. Hash browns are the superior form of breakfast potato.
author: steve m.

description: Good restaurant! I thought the food was really good. I think the hashbrowns could be a bit more browned, but overall pretty decent prices is what makes this place solid.
author: Eric A.

description:
This place is a gem. At first I came here intrigued at the idea of a Mexican diner, and it's the kind of place you'd walk right past on Mission street, but inside the atmosphere has a classic diner feel that's no frills - not your Mel's. 

There was no wait for a Sunday brunch, the food was delicious and fast, staff was friendly. The chilaquiles are the way to go, but the oatmeal pancakes also hit the spot.
author: Mindy N.

description:
This place gets the 5th star for coffee service. The only diner in the mission where I never had an empty cup.  Seriously, she even offered to refill again after she collected the check - I got the feeling I could have sat there for 3 hours and never had an empty cup.  That's just stellar stuff!

The other 4 stars are for good menu selection, having a nice atmosphere, and having nopal omelettes.

Much Recommended, it is me new pre-work joint.
author: Tyler W.

description: Want a generous portion of your favorite breakfast-American or Mexican? Go to Red's Diner. You might have to wait for a seat for a little while (Gasp! It's breakfast time!) but hold your horses and you won't be disappointed by this diner gem. Sit at the counter and watch the masterful cooks do their thing on the griddle!
author: louise z.

description: First time here went here for breakfast.Friendly Staff. I had Food quality and portion was good. Everything made fresh when order have been place. Price Reasonable. Would recommend come here if you lazy to cook at home decide to have grandma home style breakfast serve.
author: Gruber T.

description:
Just tried this place today and I'd definitely go back. My breakfast companion found his scrambled eggs a little too greasy, but my huevos a la mexicana were delicious, with nice fresh ingredients, and the beans and tortillas that came with were also great. 

And the service was nice! And the coffee was good! And they did not overcook the bacon! The only thing I wasn't in love with were the hash browns, but a good hash brown is hard to find so I will forgive them.
author: Heather R.

description: Here is an inexpensive diner that just gets it right.  I don't know if they always have the same cook, but the days I've been there, she has made everything with skill.  Diners usually serve terrible scrambled eggs.  The chef here knows how to make fluffy, buttery scrambled eggs.  Everyone here is really nice.  My 8-year-old and I absolutely love Red Cafe. (Today I noticed a line--it's nice to see that they are doing good business on the weekend, because they totally deserve it.)
author: Kathy R.

description:
After desperately looking for a hangover cure on Sunday morning, I finally found my spot-- this good ol' fashioned bacon n eggs joint named the Red Cafe. I didn't find any of the communist propaganda as the name may have suggested, but if red is the color of love, I now have a new sunday morning haven alternative to Pork Store. 

The menu here is pretty standard fare for breakfast diner, and the prices, thankfully, are also pretty standard. They had a few interesting choices--cactus omelette for example, but I wasn't as brave this morning and went with the ever-predictable Santa Fe omellete. I'm only giving this place 4 stars because there were a few annoying kids here who wouldn't stop screaming. Aside from that, good food, good service, fast cooking.
author: Jared J.

description:
**BRUNCH REVIEW ONLY**

A little breakfast/brunch place in the Mission that's not about the scene? Sign me up! We went by on a Saturday around 11-noon and was seated within minutes. In addition to the usual brunch items of omelettes/scrambles, they have some mexican classics like huevos rancheros and machaca. I actually went for a plate of eggs with fried plantains, black beans, and sour cream (platanos casamientos). Yum!
author: Angi C.

description: After reading good reviews of this place I decided to give it a try. Wat caught my attention was that they had chilaquilles. And I'm a huge fan of them! So the day I went with a couple of friends i decided to order the day I went. But I knew it was a failure when my plate arrived. Where's the sauce???? They're DRY!! WTF!? If I wanted some dry chillaquilles then trust me I would of just bought some spicy doritos! The chillaquilles weren't good! they weren't even chillaquilles! If u want good chillaquilles go to jellys cafe.... But be warn they're notbon the menu! But if u know about it they'll make them for u, and it comes with egg any style and a side if black beans or home fries. For the same price as here. Jellyscafe.com
author: Silvia C.

description: It's real(!).  It's good.  It's inexpensive.  It's friendly.  It's no frills.  It's diner food like diner food is supposed to be and not some place trying to be a diner that is fancy and nice and can't cook an egg to save their lives!
author: Mark M.

description:
great little spot for a no frills breakfast, and they do a fantastic job. they're so accommodating - egg whites, replacing potato with fruit, whatever you want. and i dig the very understated ambiance. 

i think the service is what brings it from 4 stars to 5 stars!
author: Latte Queen W.

description: I came back here and the food was on point!  The platanos were yummy, and the carne deshilada hit the spot.  I will be back. Service still sucks though, and they try to overcharge you for things without telling you. It has happened to me and other people I know that come here.
author: H. A.

description:
I LOVE THE FOOD HERE!
Breakfast is so good. Service for the gentlemen is pretty great, the manager woman sometimes not the same. But that is not the reason for the missing stars. Though their food is great. I noticed if you pay with I card they charge additional money on the card, and I know some resturants do that, but I didn't think they did. I knew they did this but usually it was less then 2 dollars so I kept that in mind while I tipped. But when my friend paid, she called me and said we never spent 25 dollars at red cafe. We usually order the same thing, so it should have been 19 dollars, and I saw the credit card statement and it was exactly a 25 dollar charge. IF YOU GO HERE, PAY WITH CASH, DO NOT PAY WITH CARD.
author: Moe o.

description: The food is good but a little overpriced. Regardless, I usually made it in there often. The last time I had breakfast there, it was a weekend and busy like normal on a Sunday. My friend ordered a breakfast quesadilla and asked if he could have meat in his quesadilla. The waiter said, "Sure, what would you like? Steak? Ham? Bacon?" And so my friend said he wanted steak. We got our food and it was very good, like expected, but our bill was not. We were charged $7.99 for a piece of thin steak no bigger than the size of your palm. I asked the waiter about it and he said that we ordered a side of steak. He did nothing for customer service so I paid for three meals and won't be going back.
author: Tiffany B.

description: Holy crap, my fiance and I went here for breakfast and we weren't disappointed! I had the two eggs, with hashbrowns, sausage and toast. He had the buttermilk pancakes. They were both absolutely perfect! The eggs were a little firm and buttery, which is how I like them. The hashbrowns were perfect, crispy outside but yielding inside. plus they had BACON SALT on the table for seasoning! Freakin' awesome. Plus breakfast for us both cost like 17 bucks! I am a fan and will be back for sure.
author: Jessica R.

description: It did the job but nothing special. Portions were a little small for me. I just had steak and eggs which were decent but ordered ranchero sauce for the eggs. Being in the Mission I expected real ranchero sauce but instead just got a cup of canned salsa. My friend got a bacon and avocado omelette that looked decent but small. I expected more after reading the reviews.
author: Craig G.

description:
This place is a block away from me.
I remember eating here long ago, but tried it out again this morning.
I decided on the open faced omelette, which had chicken, green onions, mushrooms, and your choice of bacon or ham with hash browns on the side and toast.
This was the JUICIEST omelette I've ever had in my life.  I'm not sure if that's the right word for it, but it was very tasty and had lots of flavor.
Definitely worth the price.
My manfriend ordered the steak and eggs, and demanded that I add that his steak was delicious and that he would definitely return for the steak.
Two breakfast meals and two Cokes = $22.
Not bad.
AND THEY HAVE BACON SALT ON EVERY TABLE!
!!!!!!!!
The service was very friendly and attentive.  We arrived before noon and the place was packed with mostly neighborhood families.  They had a live band playing music, which was kind of cool but could be terrifying/annoying as hell if you were suffering from a massive hangover.  
All in all, I would return for the convenience but I'm into more traditional weekend brunches (hollandaise sauce!!!)
BACON SALT!
author: Meh M.

description:
Brunch with a Spanish flare.

You have a choice of flour or corn tortillas with your meal.  The omlette was very tasty, potatoes were crispy and spiced well, and the customer service was friendly and helpful.  They even keep the vagrants out. 

Definitely a place I will be hitting up for breakfast.
author: Po L.

description: i am a fan.  i haven't been "wowed" by a breakfast in a very long time, if ever.  i got the huevos rancheros and could almost have licked my plate it was that good.  service was great, got a table right away, they have a huge stack of high chairs for the kiddos.  so long st. francis!
author: chris m.

description: Finally made it to Red Cafe after living around the corner my whole life...and I can't believe I waited so long! I ordered and devoured the Platanos con Casamientos, which is Plaintains with sour cream and fresh mexican cheese, two eggs and casamientos (a rice/bean mixture that is amazing) with tortillas on the side. SO FREAKING GOOD. I will be returning as many times as I can! (not to mention the total was under $20 for breakfast for both me and my boyfriend!)
author: Miquela S.

description:
I ate here just the other day before flying back to crappy St. Louis and have to say this place is top notch. 

Service was great (the waiter didn't bother me too much but at the same time he did refill my coffee, etc..) and the food was tremendous. 

I had the platanos casamientos and it was so damn good...

San Francisco has some awesome restaurants.
author: Mike V.

description: Awesome little classic diner in the mission. The fried plantains and huevos rancheros were fresh and tasty. I will definitely come back!
author: Suzanne G.

description: Great tasting food but the "gnat" wall decoration makes it really hard to swallow your food.  I probably won't be coming back here any time soon.  So Sad :(
author: Rachel K.

description:
not so good. 

went expecting good chilaquiles - per other reviews.  when I got them, I had to dump every bit of salsa, sour cream, hot sauce they gave me and a ton of salt just to get some taste in it.  very bland and unevenly cooked.

tried my girlfriend's hashbrowns, tasted the same.  had to pour on salt.  her corned beef hash was okay. meaning, it had a faint taste of corned beef hash.
author: Andrew T.

description: Ordered eggs a la mexicana. It came with hash browns. I asked for salsa and they brought me an ounce of hot chunky tomato soup and added a charge of $1.50 on my bill- sneaky. When I told them that I am not normally charged for salsa, the waitress replied that you only get that free at taco places- hmm. The proper thing to do is to tell your customer when you will be charged extra for condiments. This place is not worth returning to. It is not authentic. There are so many more places worth giving attention to.
author: kim y.

description: went here with a friend , gooooood food. nice employees. no waiting ,
author: Ray E.

description:
i put red cafe in the same category as howard's cafe.  cheap, yet solid eats.

they are a notch above though, as the portions are a bit larger, and the diner has a really cozy neighborhood vibe.  it's also very well kept and clean.  food was cooked well, not too greasy.  hash browns crispy!

plus i don't know too many places that serve fried plantains as a side item, do you?  :-)

breakfast special, side of plaintains, oatmeal pancakes, side of hash browns, coffee, & hot chocolate = $22
author: Josie M.

description: I love this place... so so so good.. And really cheap.. Good coffee, great French toast, great omelets and even better service... Now i am a breakfast snob so this is a tall order from me! I highly recommend checking this place out... I mean fo two people under 20 bucks how can you go wrong?
author: Samantha R.

description: I live half a block from this place.  I used to come here all the time.  The food is decent, greasy but what do you except from the quick breakfast spot on the corner.  The service has always bordered on shitty, however I put up with it as it was super close and rather tasty.  The last time I ate there however will be my last.  My dining companion had ordered hashbrowns and though the hb here are usually crispy and delicious these were barely cooked.  Ok, when the waiter came by we politely asked if he could put them back on the grill to  crisp them up some.  He did not return with them until we had finished all of our food, and they were still limp and white :-( .  This in and of itself would not be enough to warrant such a dismal review, however when I asked him to take the hashbrowns off the bill as they were not good etc. he argued with me and refused.  I explained that I came in there all the time, which he acknowledged, and that he could either take the 2.45 off the bill (A LOT for a dinky ass order of hashbrowns anyway, no?!?) or that it would be the last time I ate there.  He explained that that was how they served their hashbrowns unless you order them crispy.  I have had hashbrowns there many times, never asked for them crispy, and they were never limp and white as they were this time.  And he left them on the bill.  I will not be back.
author: Jess H.

description: Well I haven't eaten there, but I will. I just stopped by and really had to pee. They let me use their bathroom no problem. Five stars for being good people. And it smelled good in there.
author: Emily S.

description: Very friendly staff, quick food, cozy diner-like environment. Happily sat at the bar and had a delicious whites-only scramble with lots of tasty veggies. We were also fortunate enough to be serenaded by two gentlemen with a guitar and accordion. While the whole restaurant was enjoying their songs the staff were quietly singing along. It was a great little brunch moment. Will definitely go here again!
author: Tiff C.

description: I can't believe the reviews this place got. I recently went there and I did not enjoy the experience.
author: Paula O.

description: This place rocks. The food is delicious,  the service is great, and the prices are reasonable. I recommend the huevos (eggs) rancheros for breakfast and the crispy chicken sandwich for lunch.
author: Abdallah E.

description: I took my family to this spot based on the reviews it received but I must say it was nothing GREAT. The place was packed,staff was good but food was just bland.
author: Manuel D.

description: For the life of me I can't understand why this place was rated so well by others.  The food selection was basic and cooked like a house wife who was in a hurry would cook.   The service while not unpleasant was only average. There wasn't one piece of art on the walls.  A couple of maroon carpet rugs with rubber backing were on the floor.  The table tops were worn down in bare wood in spots. Will not return.
author: Greg K.

description: Deduce what you might, but I am often found judging books by their covers. Submitting to intense pressure and without an obvious convenient alternative of my own, I ended up walking into this nondescript corner restaurant called Red Cafe for breakfast. Since that initial encounter, I've found myself there another 3 or 4 times but willingly and obviously repentant for the errors of what, in hindsight, appears to have been a lapse in judgment on my part. I am seriously crushing on the plantains and egg dish that comes with the casamiento (rice and beans in a ball). The sweet plantains were the perfect balance when paired with the white cheese that comes with. In my defense, I think that whoever can concoct such a savory dish, deserves a better outwardly appearance. Or, rather, from the quantity of reviews this place has received on yelp, I would say most yelpers are not as hasty or shallow as I am in such important culinary matters.
author: Jane K.

description: This is a nicely low-key diner in the Mission.  We were seated and served quickly, and it wasn't overrun with hipsters like some of the other local places.  The scrambled eggs were good, and my wife (a bacon connoisseur by now) praised their bacon.  This is definitely getting added to our brunch repertoire.
author: Joe H.

description: I was pleasantly surprised.  I love hash browns and Red Cafe makes them really crispy on the outside and mushy on the inside.  Add some catsup and tabasco and they are heavenly.  Well that's what I do.  I also appreciate the various Salvadorean options on the menu.  I would stick to coming here for breakfast and/or brunch.  The service was attentive the day I went (my coffee was bottomless).
author: Adrian N.

description:
i only remember having some pupusas here... they were tasty and freshly made to order
regret not going here more often when i used to live a block away but i guess that's how it goes... you figure you'll always get a chance to go since it's so close by... and then time flies by and you've moved to a different address... so typical
author: charlotte s.

description: I like the fact that this place is close to my house and doesn't have a wait but our food was just... eh. Boring & bland eggs, hash browns, etc. Good in a pinch, but not the top of the list.
author: Emily B.

description: Ate here 3 times while on vacation and all three times the service was HORRIBLE. Food was what you would expect but my friend got one hell of a good burger. The third (and last) time, the waitress was such a bitch about fresh fruit ("(Why don't you just go to a grocery store?") that I left 43 cents for a tip. I used to wait tables and not only had that NEVER happened to me, but thats the only time I ever did it to another wait staff.
author: Lee M.

description:
In my opinion, the best thing about this restaurant is the friendly service. From the time I put my name on the list, the host addressed me by name, including when he held the door for me as I left. As for the food: I had the huevos rancheros, listed as Eggs Rancheros - not sure why, since everyone in this town understands huevos, even the more colorful meanings. Anyway... the eggs were over easy with a salsa picante, there were hash browns and refried black beans. I had corn tortillas rather than the other choice which I think was toast. As soon as I ordered "huevos rancheros" the waiter started speaking to me in Spanish, which I thought was great since I like to try to stay conversant. Lots of places won't give you the time of day in Spanish unless you don't speak English.
The eggs with the salsa were great, the refried black beans had been pureed to within an inch of their lives and the corn tortillas were straight out of a package. I can't really fault them for that, considering the very reasonable menu prices, but the refried beans were soupy on top of having the consistency of baby food (to be kind...ha) So, the bottom line on the food is that it was absolutely nothing special for me this morning, but the service was lovely. That's where the 4th star is coming from.
author: Phil S.

description: After years of searching, luckily my favorite breakfast place in SF is two blocks from home. Perhaps that has something to do with it. Either way, their pancakes are light - not at all gummy the way old pancake batter can be at shall-remain-unnamed other breakfast places. Plus, plantains - which solve the brunch "sweet or savory" conundrum by being both - come two ways, with refried beans and sour cream or with fresh cheese, beany rice and two eggs. Plus all your standard eggy breakfast items, some rockin' thick french toast, tasty bacon, and your tortilla/burrito/papusa options as well. Sit at the counter and you'll get to watch the well coordinated grill and kitchen and leave smelling of all things breakfast.
author: Lauren G.

description: I was looking for a new breakfast place to eat on Saturday morning, and my hubby told me about a place on Mission street called "Red Cafe".  I decided to go, and I am so glad i did.  I ordered the oatmeal pancakes with fruit on top......it was yummy in my tummy!  I am definitely coming back for more of everything on the menu.  The only downfall about coming here to eat, is the parking.  It was very hard to find parking that day, even in the morning?  Who knew.
author: Victoria S.

description: Awesome! Everything on the menu sounded tempting, and out of 5 of us, everything we got was great. The mariachi band playing live music was a nice touch for this hole-in-the wall diner style cafe. I would definitely go back again for some more.
author: Antara B.

description: I was very hungover, in dire need of coffee, and even though it was impossible to find parking, and it was raining like a bitch, this place raised my mood. The coffee was intense... and pure. The jalapenos in my eggs had that proper kick that you sometimes don't get in some of these breakfast joints. I loved the vibe of the place... very old school diner, almost east coast.
author: Evan K.

description: A great alternative to some of the Mission's more trendy breakfast spots, the Red Caf is a fantastic place to have a sit down with the previous night's hang-over.  The food here is really good and moderately priced, the servers are all so lovely and friendly, and their corned beef hash sandwich fucking rocks.  Just be warned, if wandering Mariachis have an adverse affect on your hang-over, you might want to try another venue.  Fortunately for me, I kinda have a thing for Mariachi music.
author: Broke-Ass Stuart S.

description: Boogawho? Red Cafe rules the roost over all the other breakfast/Iunch spots in the neighborhood. I love a place where you can just plop down at the counter and be knee deep in huevos rancheros witthin seconds. No need to wait for twenty minutes amidst a sea of stupid scenesters on the sidewalk out front. Service is always friendly and prompt. Nothing fancy about the decor, but why should that detract from the deliciousness that's perched on your plate, eh? On a more somber note, last time I was there I had to sit next to some crazy old white power dude with really shitty lightning bolts tattooed on his neck. I don't appreciate someone judging my breakfast as "racially impure." Apart from that, I've never had a bad breakfast at Red Cafe.
author: Steven C.

description: Family-style laid back alternative to the busy breakfast usuals in the Mission. Chilaquiles scramble, Heuvos Rancheros, Oatmeal Pancakes, good coffee, and all the standards if you're feeling boring. Good coffee.
author: Blaine C.

description: The staff is super nice! The food...well, it's good diner food and a little greasy but overall, not bad if you want to eat a ton. A little bit on the pricey side but you get a lot of food for your money. Their breakfasts are good and so are their lunches, especially their grilled cheese and veggie burgers.
author: Gina R.

description: A Mission Street Diner. Refurbished and managed to keep the style and warmth of days gone by.  Food is plentiful, do not miss the pancakes "fluffy and moist."  A better deal one cannot find for its central accessibility. Hipster stay away, we want short lines.
author: One P.

description: 3.5 really, The service was good and the food was okay. I judge all breakfast places by their two eggs, hash brown, and pick of meat combo. It was wasn't anything too special, but a solid place. Oh, and their booths are funny shaped where the sitting area is smaller than the table. At least the middle sitting area was like that. Weird.
author: Emily A.

description: Me gusta la Red Cafe. yep, it's one of my favorite places to go sit at the counter (no waiting), order my corned beef hash, read the sunday paper and inadvertently eavesdrop on the goings-on of the various Spanish speaking regulars that come to this no nonsense cafe. The potatoes are just the right crispiness, the corned beef a healthy heaping serving, and the eggs done right. Si senorita.
author: ray e.

description: Come here for the platanos con casamiento, it is a tasty alternative to your usual eggs and bacon dish. The serving staff is always friendly and makes you feel at home. Breakfast is always hot and they use fresh ingredients ta boot. Great neighborhood joint, always a pleasure!
author: Erika Y.

description: The corned beef hash with poached eggs here is smooth and delish, enhanced with 'shooms. A standard plantains and sour cream kind of has identity crisis: is it breakfast or dessert? The rice and black bean mash-up is really good, too, and the giant glass of freshly squeezed ohjay is excessive acid. Friendly, attentive service, even in a jam-packed house. Surprisingly nice for a Mission joint.
author: Maximillian M.

description: On the corner of 25th and Mission, this unassuming nook serves some really good stuff.  Unaware that platanos could be classified as a breakfast item, I decided to take a chance.  To my delight, it tasted really yummy, and was quite filling.  I was too full to sample the food off of my daughter's pancake plate.  But seeing that she actually ate some of it, so that's a good sign.  Parking is never easy in the Mission, but sometimes you get lucky.  And the day that I found parking in front of this place, and ate there, I felt especially luckful
author: brenda b.

description: Some of the best pancakes I have ever had (sorry Mum!).  Not fancy by any means, but just perfectly executed white fluffy pancakes.  Huevos Rancheros was pretty good too - the tortillas were tasty and fresh.  Service was very friendly.  Coffee was below average and the hash browns were plain.  In short, go for the friendly service, nice atmosphere, and phenomenal pancakes.
author: Jon K.

description: Ok, am i wrong, or are chilaquiles basically breakfast nachos? No, I'm not knocking the concept of breakfast nachos. In fact, I think it's kind of brilliant. My date and I went here for breakfast and I had the chilaquiles which I thoroughly enjoyed (although i'm not the right person to attest to the authenticity of them). My date had an omlette or a scramble or something that he wasn't entirely satisfied with. If I were judging on the chilaquiles alone, I'd give Red Cafe 4 stars. There's a small knock for not refilling our coffees enough. Small ceramic coffee mugs- we drink fast;
author: Ann F.

description: Not sure if I love this place quite as much as St. Francis, but the scrambled eggs were just right (very flavorful-- wonder if they use my mom's old trick of scrambling them in a tiny bit of bacon grease?) and the oatmeal pancakes were actually packed with oatmeal-- yum. The service was friendly, and the clientele was a little more, well,  authentically Mission (that is, plenty of Spanish was spoken) than what you see at the usual neighborhood brunch hangouts.
author: Heather M.

description:
I went a head and gave three stars, could be closer to 3.5, but with in the diner genre it's a more than decent American diner with Latin flare and for the Mission meets the three star rating or a bit more. All the fare you would expect at any diner, from burgers, salads, sandwiches to eggs, bacon and pancakes. Throw in some Latin breakfast choices like the Nopales omelet, which I had and it was good, more frittata like and just a bit of cheese melted on the top. Not as greasy as some of the other reviewers suggested. In fact, I find the Pork store greasier and frankly too much food at times. The portions were right on.
 I was alone and sat at the bar with no waiting on a Sunday afternoon. It was busy with just a few places at the counter  where you can watch the ladies cooking. Kind of a change seeing women doing all the cooking and the wait staff a mix of men and women. Lots of staff on hand. The service was attentive and friendly and the Mariachis came in just as I sat down. Not the overwhelmingly loud version I am used to . Very festive. A few songs at the back of the room and then off they went. 
If you order a sandwich it comes with choice of onion rings, fries or Ceasar salad, which all looked good. I noticed the burgers were hand formed and the meat looked like it had never been frozen. 
If you don't live in the neighborhood or can't get there easily then don't make a special trip as I am sure you can find a diner in your area, but for us folks in the Mission with limited breakfast/hamburger type choices this is a convenient find and a nice alternative to La Taza  and with wait service. There's some love here.
author: Terri S.

description: I love greasy spoon diners, this place is "le bomb" and affordable for bfast or lunch.
author: erica u.

description: This place has a mix of east-coast breakfast-diner-y food with a Central American bent. Whatever. The coffee's decent and the eggs come from chickens that I guess are only fed a diet of butter. I'd go there again.
author: Jon G.

description: I love love love this place.  Boyfriend and I come here for breakfast practically every weekend, and every time we try somewhere else we both kind of wish we'd just gone back to Red Cafe.  The plantains are delicious, and all of the Mexican options are amazing (disclaimer: I don't eat meat, so can't comment on that).  In the American section of the menu, I highly recommend the oatmeal pancakes with strawberries.  All delicious and cheap.  The staff are super nice, service is fast and efficient, and we've never had to wait more than 10 minutes to be seated.  Oh and the fresh orange juice is FRESH.  There is nothing I don't love about Red Cafe.
author: Sarah B.

description: Great breakfast. Delicious garden scramble, carne deshilachada and pancakes. Great for an inexpensive Sunday morning.  Very nice service.
author: Diego V.

description:
I ate here one time.  

The meal was not cheap.
The food was nothing special.
The portions were not huge.

I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone for any reason.
author: Henry C.

description: I had breakfast here with my friend the other day.  We just walked in and were seated right away.  The service here is very laid back.  We both ordered breakfast burrito with hash browns (the menu said meals come with hash browns unless otherwise noted).  There was no mention of the burritos not including hash browns.  The food was pretty good.  When we got the bill, we were both charged an extra 2 dollars for the hash browns.  I even had a feeling we were going to be charged for them since they took awhile to come out after our main dishes.  just double check how much they are charging you.
author: Joey M.

description: Again, Yelp did not let me down.  The Red Cafe is a cozy, inexpensive diner with yummy food and friendly staff.  We didn't have to wait long to eat on a Sunday morning.  The oatmeal pancakes with bananas were good - not the best I've had, but very satisfying for $6.95.  Not a place for big groups, but comfortable for our foursome.  Recommended!
author: Jenny G.

description: Solid 4 star coffee shop w/ a latin flare. I've had great experiences w/ the owner(s) and staff and coming here has been a near weekly treat for me over the last 9 months. Juevos rancheros, with a side of fresh jalepenos is my favorite dish. The burgers look amazing although I haven't tried them yet. The platanos and casamiento are great. Overall, a perfect lazy Saturday or Sunday late breakfast or lunch spot.
author: Brian W.

description: Favorite breakfast spot in SF hands down. The service is great, the atmosphere is always fun, and the chilaquiles are amazing! Great prices for a great and fast breakfast.
author: L. S.

description: this place has kinda been hiding from me? or i haven't been paying enough attention... went there this morning for a late breakfast. they serve breakfast ALL DAY! love those places as long as they can beat out denny's lameness. i got the mushroom/avo omelet with fresh fruit. they didn't have rye (wah) but whatever, it rocked. i was thinking they would have more mex dishes but it's all good. they have plantain! i'll be back for that next time. great service too!
author: Ash G.

description: Absolutely fantastic Mexican breakfast spot. Great location, speedy service, enormous portions and well priced. The bar is a fun spot to sit and watch them crank out orders at lightning speed in front of your eyes. Have never had anything other than a great experience.
author: Andres G.

description: This place is solid. Nothing fancy, none of the crazy wait for 2 hours crowds that I'm used to around SF. Great friendly staff, good food, and I can get a breakfast burrito or huevos rancheros.........oh if you're feeling adventurous, the plaintains and beans are a really good alternative breakfast....
author: Kevin A.

description: I tried this place for the first time today and was so happy I did!  It was crowded when we arrived, but we only had to wait 5 min before grabbing a corner spot at the counter. I had the chilaquiles, which were some of the best I've ever tasted.  (crispy tortilla strips and excellent beans and green chili sauce on the side) We also had a side of plantains, which were great on their own and even better when paired with the beans. The portions are hearty - definitely large enough to share, especially if you get something small on the side as well.  We will be back!
author: Brynne D.

description: horrible customer service! and really rude.  the only thing that saves them is that the food was decent,
author: Princess P.

description: you'd probably miss this place if you weren't paying attention. it doesn't really stick out but i was starving and it was the first thing i saw so i figured to give it a shot. it's pretty small inside and the decor is really nothing special. the kitchen is open so you can see them cooking. i noticed that there were mostly women working there..i saw one man, looked like he might have done dishes. awesome. we had breakfast and everyone was pretty good for the price. the vegetarian omelet was good and it came with hash browns and toast. we were all pleased with our orders and the waitress was attentive. i'd eat there again, there are many things to choose from.
author: monica p.

description: Red Cafe is a completely solid, Mexican-American greasy spoon.  I wouldn't necessarily say the food was anything to write home about, but it certainly held it's own.  Combine that with the fact that the service was solid, the prices are decent, and the location's convenient, and you've got yourself a win.
author: Patrick P.

description: My experience with Red Cafe's menu is admittedly limited as the only thing I get from here are the pupusas. I lived in Honduras for a while last year and fell in love with these "stuffed tortillas".  The curtido, a cabbage salad served with pupusas, is great, just the right amount of vinegar and spice.
author: dissipatedfog ..

description: I was running errands in the mission with a little time to kill and a local suggested I walk down the street to try this place. I definitely felt it was a popular local breakfast joint with only available seating at the bar. Service was friendly and efficient. I ordered the breakfast quesadilla, orange juice and side of hash browns. First of all I have to say the orange juice was fresh and REAL, I don't know how many times I've been upset by spending 5$ on a small glass of Minute Maid garbage juice. The semi open kitchen design allowed me to watch them cook my meal which is always a bonus. The hash browns were standard, nothing a little salt and pepper can't fix. The quesadilla was not only huge it was delicious, I was unable to eat the entire meal. I packed the leftovers in a bag and enjoyed them later on that evening. I am a fan, if I find myself in the mission again I'll return for breakfast.
author: R J.

description: great little diner with mex and american breakfast food.. super kid friendly.   Good but not outstanding food but cheap and quick service
author: Tiffany S.

description: Red Cafe is what it is.  Its a diner style place.  I have tried the Breakfast Burrito and the Cheeseburger and Fries.  How to really explain??  The Cheeseburger is a nice sized patty, a toasted bun, lettuce, tomato, and a few condiments.  Special sauce, mayo and mustard.  While this all sounds basic, its really simple and tasty.  The is the great burger drip that everyone knows what I am talking about.  There is the almost perfect diner french fries.  And then there is the price.  I got 2 cheeseburgers and fries for less than $13.  Burger and fries.  It is really a way of life.  In the morning the breakfast foods are fantastic.  The breakfast burrito is awesome to behold.  My only complaint about it is they don't have a side of hash browns to accompany the cheesy tasty awesomeness that will soon be entering your body.  But I like to order them and eat bites with or separately.  The service is really quick.  And I actually enjoy the club type music they play inside.  Its like the party in my mouth is dancing with the music.  I go here a lot and so should you!!!   They have a lot of different foods all are pretty decent.
author: Jerry V.

description: excellent placa i think it deserves more reviews from people of course good ones , hashbrowns are perfect , definetly better than overrated toast will be going back more for sure to try their lunch
author: NAEL K.

description: i love this place! especially that it's mostly families from the neighborhood, the employees are so nice, and it's the perfect diner food the morning after binge drinking.  i don't even really wanna say anymore, because if the hipsters take over this spot, and rob me of another diner,  i just might fucking lose it.
author: Angie B.

description: This place switch hits, going one way for we fat americans who love our big classic breakfasts, but going to the other side of the plate for those who like plantains, beans and juevos rancheros for their numero uno desayuno.  One thing that kind of annoys me: they serve their toast a little cold and undercooked with the butter cold and wrapped in those little foil packets. So by the time you unwrap it and try to get it on your tooast or english muffin or rye, the melting factor has diminished significantly. But that s me...all i do is crush melted butter on toast.
author: Galen m.

description: the food was worse than the service! and i also felt a strong undertone of discrimination and prejudice as i watched the tables around me receive excellent service. with the exception of the crawfish, ALL of the seafood is processed frozen things that you could find better quality of at a supermarket.
author: EL B.

description: this place is amazing.  i've had many breakfasts here some as late as 2pm. its this tiny little place that feels like home from the first time you go there. everything is delicious and fresh and relatively healthy compared to other breakfast places.  oh and there's usually really good music playing.
author: adams l.

description: This place is great!  I stopped by for the first time today for breakfast and ordered the Huevos Rancheros which were delish--salsa good and  beans great.  I ordered a side of pancakes and they were also yummy.  PRompt service. Everything awesome. I will definitely return!
author: Jessica G.

description: I have been here twice for breakfast and both times have been completely satisfied with the food.  I ordered the Mexicana plato, the one with eggs jalapeos refried beans and tortillas.  I'm usually the bland breakfast type, not too much sugar not too much spice, however, this restaurant changed that all! The meal was just right amount of spicy. The staff at the Red Cafe is incredible nice and accommodating.  I am giving this place 5 stars because of the menu, the service and location.
author: adre w.

description: I would never had thought that a good pancake restaurant would be discovered in the middle of the Mission District.  Again, based on the reviews of the fellow Yelp reviewers and a massive craving for pancakes all of a sudden, we decided to try it out.  Parking was a bit hard on a Saturday afternoon, however we were not deterred.  Finally finding that free, one-hour parking space (HOORAY!), we walked to Red.  We had the Combinations and Chicken sandwich.  The pancake was delicious!  Possibly because I was famished or my love of sweet hit me right then and there, but that pancake was buttery!  Price was right for two dishes, atmosphere small yet cozy, food was the right portion.  Definitely a "good eats" place.
author: Restaurant C.
